<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 304, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 260, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 330, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 590, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 527, 606, 543]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 558, 606, 573]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 574, 756, 590]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 590, 440, 605]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 606, 907, 636]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length \(0.6 \mathrm{m}\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\) of a smooth horizontal plane. \(P\) moves on the plane at constant speed \(5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) in a circle with centre \(O\). Calculate the tension in the string. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 152, 96, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 161, 687, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 307, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
A uniform frame consists of a semicircular arc \(ABC\) of radius \(0.6 \mathrm{m}\) together with its diameter \(AOC\), where \(O\) is the centre of the semicircle (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 354, 153, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 354, 677, 373]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance of the centre of mass of the frame from \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 608, 403]]<|/det|>
The frame is freely suspended at \(A\) and hangs in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 415, 153, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 415, 549, 434]]<|/det|>
Calculate the angle between \(AC\) and the vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 416, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 462, 94, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.8 \mathrm{kg}\) moves along the \(x\)-axis on a horizontal surface. When the displacement of \(P\) from the origin \(O\) is \(x \mathrm{m}\) the velocity of \(P\) is \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) in the positive \(x\)-direction. Two horizontal forces act on \(P\). One force has magnitude \(4\mathrm{e}^{- x}\mathrm{N}\) and acts in the positive \(x\)-direction. The other force has magnitude \(2.4x^{2}\mathrm{N}\) and acts in the negative \(x\)-direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 545, 153, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 545, 390, 565]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\nu \frac{\mathrm{d}\nu}{\mathrm{d}x} = 5\mathrm{e}^{-x} - 3x^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 548, 920, 566]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 585, 151, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 585, 843, 604]]<|/det|>
The velocity of \(P\) as it passes through \(O\) is \(6 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). Find the velocity of \(P\) when \(x = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 632, 97, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
A small ball \(B\) is projected from a point \(O\) with speed \(14 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) above the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 663, 156, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 663, 836, 682]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed and direction of motion of \(B\) for the instant 1.8 s after projection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 694, 475, 713]]<|/det|>
The point \(O\) is \(2 \mathrm{m}\) above a horizontal plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 725, 153, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 725, 645, 744]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time after projection when \(B\) reaches the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 726, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 83, 650, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 288, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) is attached to a fixed point \(A\) by a light inextensible string of length \(0.4 \mathrm{m}\). A second light inextensible string of length \(0.3 \mathrm{m}\) connects \(P\) to a fixed point \(B\) which is vertically below \(A\). The particle \(P\) moves in a horizontal circle, which has its centre on the line \(AB\), with the angle \(APB = 90^{\circ}\) (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 367, 151, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 767, 386]]<|/det|>
Given that the tensions in the two strings are equal, calculate the speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 397, 153, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 397, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that \(P\) moves with its least possible angular speed for motion in this circle. Find this angular speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 459, 96, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[266, 470, 767, 625]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 644, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
\(ABCD\) is the cross-section through the centre of mass of a uniform rectangular block of weight \(260 \mathrm{N}\). The lengths \(AB\) and \(BC\) are \(1.5 \mathrm{m}\) and \(0.8 \mathrm{m}\) respectively. The block rests in equilibrium with the point \(D\) on a rough horizontal floor. Equilibrium is maintained by a light rope attached to the point \(A\) on the block and the point \(E\) on the floor. The points \(E, A\) and \(B\) lie in a straight line inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 738, 156, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 738, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about \(D\), show that the tension in the rope is \(146 \mathrm{N}\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 755, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 785, 156, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 784, 920, 817]]<|/det|>
Given that the block is in limiting equilibrium, calculate the coefficient of friction between the block and the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 861, 670, 881]]<|/det|>
[Question 7 is printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{kg}\) is attached to one end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.8 \mathrm{m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(32 \mathrm{N}.\) The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The particle is released from rest at \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 153, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 134, 804, 153]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(OP\) at the instant when \(P\) first comes to instantaneous rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
A horizontal plane is fixed at a distance \(1 \mathrm{m}\) below \(O\). The particle \(P\) is again released from rest at \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 197, 151, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 197, 720, 215]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of \(P\) immediately before it collides with the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 151, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 227, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
In the collision with the plane, \(P\) loses \(96\%\) of its kinetic energy. Calculate the distance \(OP\) at the instant when \(P\) first comes to instantaneous rest above the plane, given that this occurs when the string is slack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 260, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
